text:
ABBY FALIK: Today's kids are
encouraged to play it safe.

Everything's become
this high stakes game
to get into college.

In that context, taking
risks and exploring

authentic interests
isn't on the checklist.

The human skills of the future
can't be taught in a classroom
alone.

Skills like empathy, creativity,
curiosity, collaboration,

these are the things that
the robots will never do.

At Global Citizen Year,
we are reinventing

the path between high
school and college

to give young people
the opportunity

to figure out who
they are when they're
outside of their comfort zone.
[NON-ENGLISH SPEECH]

Each year, we recruit and select
a diverse cohort of really
high-potential young people.

We take them through
a 10-month leadership

course in countries
across Africa, Asia,
and Latin America.

And when they come
back and begin college,

it's with a set of
burning questions.

They're ready to declare
a major and a mission.
They know their why.
[CHEERING]

It's been nearly 10
years now that we've

been working to build this
organization and the broader
movement.

Starting a new organization
from scratch hasn't been easy.

I've really come to
embrace the rejections

and the disappointments and
the innumerable no's as gifts.

What keeps me going
is knowing that
what we're doing changes lives.

I know through experience that
ideas don't change the world;
people do.
Leaders change the world.

If we can change the leaders
who change the world,

we can build the world
we all want to live in.
